New Records: Wyatt Langford became the first Rangers rookie to win a game with a walk-off grand slam.
He is the 24th rookie since 1944 to hit a walk-off grand slam and the first since Francisco Mejia in September 2018.
Langford is the seventh-youngest MLB player to hit a walk-off grand slam and the youngest American League player to ever, at 22 years, and 293 days old.
Key Match Events: Wyatt Langford hit a walk-off grand slam in the ninth inning to lift the Texas Rangers to a 7-4 comeback win over the New York Yankees.
Langford ripped a 3-2 slider 407 feet into the second deck in the left-field corner to score the winning runs.
Pre-Game Insights: There are no pre-game insights mentioned in the article.
Post-Match Reflections: Langford expressed his satisfaction in coming through in a clutch situation.
Rangers manager Bruce Bochy praised Langford's ability to handle the pressure and make big hits.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was a comeback win for the Rangers, who trailed 4-3 with one out and the bases loaded.
Langford has a team-leading three walk-off hits, the most by a Rangers player since Josh Hamilton had three in 2011.
Others: The article mentions that Langford has been on the rough end of a plenty of controversial strike calls during his rookie season.
